title: Updated Value Proposition Canvas
goal: Show the customer pains/gains + how Harvest & Co. delivers value.

sections.title: Brand purpose, vision, mission
body: Brand Purpose (Revised): To make ethical, sustainable dining accessible to everyone by serving responsibly sourced food at fair, everyday prices—supporting local communities while reducing environmental impact.
Brand Vision (Revised): To become the West Midlands’ most trusted accessible ethical dining brand—where choosing sustainable, locally sourced food is easy, affordable, and part of everyday life.

Brand Mission (Revised): Harvest & Co.’s mission is to deliver high-quality casual dining that balances sustainability with affordability. We will source locally wherever possible, minimise waste, and operate responsibly—while maintaining consistent food quality, warm hospitality, and reliable value across all six locations.

sections.title: Brand values framework
body: Accessible Ethics: Sustainability should be realistic and affordable, not exclusive or premium-priced. Customers experience clear value-for-money menus, ethical options at different price points, and transparent pricing.

Local First: Prioritising local producers and suppliers to strengthen community and reduce food miles. Customers experience menus that highlight local farms, seasonal specials, and West Midlands pride.

Honest Food: Customers deserve truthful, high-quality food with transparency about ingredients and sourcing. Customers experience simple, fresh, consistent recipes, ingredient transparency, and behind-the-scenes storytelling.
Care for People: Treating guests and staff with respect, fairness, and inclusion. Customers experience friendly service, trained staff, and inclusive dining.

Responsible Impact: Operating sustainably by reducing waste and environmental impact. Customers experience visible sustainable practices, reduced food waste, and ethical choices communicated clearly without greenwashing.

Consistency & Accountability: A multi-site restaurant must deliver the same standards everywhere. Customers experience reliable menus, consistent service speed and quality, and quick resolution of complaints.

sections.title: Target market segmentation
body: Segmentation approach: demographic, geographic (West Midlands catchment areas near sites), psychographic (values, lifestyle attitudes), behavioural (dining frequency, spend sensitivity, sustainability interest).
Primary segments: Value-conscious ethical eaters (25–45, price-sensitive but quality-driven) and families seeking affordable quality (30–50, consistency and reliability across locations).
Secondary segments: Convenience-driven workers & lunch diners, occasion casual social diners, lifestyle & wellness diners.

sections.title: Customer Profile
body: Customer Jobs: Quick casual dining that feels healthy + honest; find affordable places for groups/families; make better choices without guilt or premium pricing.

Pains: Ethical food is usually expensive; confusing sustainability claims (greenwashing); inconsistent food/service across sites; limited quick/lunch-friendly options; lack of transparency about sourcing.
Gains: Affordable ethical meals; clear provenance (local suppliers); consistency across locations; seasonal variety and freshness; welcoming atmosphere with fast service.

sections.title: Value Map
body: Products & Services: Farm-to-table casual dining; seasonal menus + supplier partnerships; takeaway + lunch deals; loyalty scheme rewarding frequency.

Pain Relievers: Value bundles + clear pricing tiers; honest sourcing page on menu/website; consistency standards across 6 sites; staff training for speed + hospitality; transparent sustainability proof points.
Gain Creators: Meet-the-supplier storytelling; seasonal specials + local hero ingredient; family-friendly options; loyalty rewards tied to ethical choices.

jobs: Quick casual dining that feels “healthy + honest”
Make better choices without guilt or premium pricing

gainCreators: Loyalty rewards tied to ethical choices

title: Brand Personality & Tone of Voice Guidelines
goal: Align tone, personality, and copy rules across all touchpoints.

sections.title: Personality spectrum
body: Warm 5, Honest 5, Modern 4, Playful 3, Premium 2, Activist 2, Friendly 5.
Position Harvest & Co. as warm, honest, community-rooted, modern but not elitist, positive and never preachy.

sections.title: Tone pillars
body: Welcoming, Transparent, Local & Proud, Simple + Value-led, Positive not preachy.

sections.title: Do & Don’t guidelines
body: DO: plain English, proof-based claims, value + community.
DON’T: elite vibes, shame customers, overclaim sustainability.

sections.title: Example copy
body: Website banner: “Ethical food, everyday prices.”
Menu note: “Local ingredients. Seasonal menus. Zero fuss.”

examples: Local ingredients. Seasonal menus. Zero fuss.

title: Rebranding Objectives & Success Criteria
goal: Track success KPIs across short, medium, and long-term horizons.

sections.title: Short-term (0–6 months)
body: Improve brand clarity across all six sites | KPI +30% brand message recall (survey).
Strengthen marketing consistency | KPI 100% sites using central templates.
Increase footfall from value audience | KPI +10% weekly covers per site.

sections.title: Medium-term (6–12 months)
body: Improve online engagement and conversion | KPI +40% website booking conversion, +25% Instagram engagement.
Boost loyalty-driven revenue | KPI 25% customers enrolled in loyalty.

sections.title: Long-term (12–24 months)
body: Restore sustainable profitability | KPI +8–12% EBITDA margin, improved cash flow.
Market leadership in accessible ethical dining | KPI top-3 brand awareness in region.

short.title: Improve brand clarity across all six sites

long.title: Market leadership in accessible ethical dining

title: Brand Positioning Map (Post-Rebrand)
goal: Show the market gap Harvest & Co. owns on price accessibility vs ethical transparency.

sections.title: Map axes
body: X-axis: Price accessibility (Affordable → Expensive).
Y-axis: Ethical transparency (Low → High).

sections.title: Competitive placements
body: Harvest & Co.: High ethical transparency + high affordability.
Premium farm-to-table: High ethics, high price.
Budget chains: Low ethics, low price.
Mid casual dining: medium price, low ethics.

title: Visual Identity Concept Overview
goal: Define the visual direction and design principles.

sections.title: Direction
body: Modern farmhouse meets high-street casual.
Natural, warm, clean.

sections.title: Principles
body: Minimal clutter, visible ingredient photography, local storytelling visuals, warm neutrals + fresh greens.

title: Logo Usage Guidelines (Proposed)
goal: Protect logo integrity across environments.

sections.title: Logo rules
body: Clear space 1x logo height all sides.
Minimum size 24px digital / 20mm print.
Backgrounds: full logo on light, white logo on dark green.

sections.title: Do not
body: Do not stretch, add shadows, change colours, or place on noisy imagery.

rules: Clear space: minimum 1x logo height around all sides
Approved variations: full colour, mono dark, white reverse
Backgrounds: avoid busy imagery; use solid colours or soft overlays

title: Colour Palette & Typography System
goal: Set the core colour and type system for the rebrand.

sections.title: Colour system
body: Primary: Harvest Green, Warm Cream.
Secondary: Earth Brown, Charcoal.
Accent: Seasonal Yellow.

sections.title: Typography
body: Headings modern sans, body friendly sans, optional serif for quotes.
Hierarchy: H1 headlines, H2 headers, Body menus/descriptions, Caption sourcing info.

title: Menu Design Strategy
goal: Deliver value-led menu architecture and storytelling.

sections.title: Menu structure
body: Top section: Value bundles + “Everyday Ethical Choices”.
Middle: seasonal specials + local supplier highlight.
Bottom: children’s meals + dietary options.

sections.title: Menu copy style
body: Short, clear descriptions with provenance lines beneath key dishes.
Icons for local / seasonal / vegan / low-waste.

sections.title: Visual strategy
body: Ingredient-led photos, consistent spacing, and storytelling boxes (supplier feature).

title: Sustainability Messaging Framework
goal: Keep sustainability claims clear, proof-based, and customer-led.

sections.title: Messaging pyramid
body: Customer benefit → Proof → Values.
Sustainability must always link to customer value.

sections.title: Rules
body: Avoid vague terms (“eco-friendly”, “100% sustainable”).
Provide evidence (supplier list, targets, actions).

rules: Proof: local sourcing %, waste reduction, supplier names

title: Pricing Communication Strategy
goal: Clarify value and fairness across pricing communications.

sections.title: Key messaging
body: “Fair prices, fairly sourced.”
“Ethical dining made affordable.”

sections.title: Techniques
body: Clear bundle savings (Save £X).
Price anchors (good/better/best).
Provenance justification: “Local supplier / seasonal ingredients”.

faq.q: Why are some dishes priced higher?
faq.a: We price by ingredient quality and seasonal supply while keeping value bundles accessible.
Bundles group popular items at a lower combined price to reward frequent visits.
Core menu pricing is consistent across all six sites; local specials follow the same value tiers.

title: Centralised Marketing Governance Model
goal: Define governance roles and approvals for marketing output.

sections.title: Structure
body: Central marketing team controls brand guidelines, templates, calendar, performance tracking.
Local site role: limited local adaptation using approved content slots; submit requests for promotions/events.

title: Local Storytelling Alignment Framework
goal: Align local stories to brand pillars with a consistent format.

sections.title: Framework
body: Local stories must align to one of the brand pillars: Local suppliers, Community involvement, Seasonal food stories, Staff culture.
Standard format: Story → Customer benefit → Brand proof point.

title: Digital Brand Guidelines
goal: Ensure digital assets follow tone, accessibility, and photo guidance.

sections.title: Included guidance
body: Tone rules, templates (posts, emails, banners), accessibility compliance (contrast, alt text), photo guidance (real food, real people).

title: Social Media Content Strategy
goal: Set content pillars and cadence for social channels.

sections.title: Content pillars
body: 1. Value meals + bundles
2. Supplier storytelling
3. Seasonal menu drops
4. Staff and culture
5. Sustainability proof

sections.title: Posting plan
body: 4 posts/week, 8–12 stories/week, 1 short-form video/week.

sections.title: Goals
body: Increase engagement rate, increase booking clicks, grow reviews.

title: Website Structure and UX Improvements
goal: Align the web experience with performance and transparency goals.

sections.title: Proposed sitemap
body: Home | Menu | Locations | Book/Order | Offers | Loyalty | Our Story | Suppliers | Contact

sections.title: UX improvements
body: Fast menu filters, one-click booking/order CTA, location detection, mobile-first usability, transparent sourcing section.

title: Email Marketing and CRM Strategy
goal: Support lifecycle engagement with consistent messaging.

sections.title: Lifecycle emails
body: Welcome sequence, seasonal menu launch, bundle offers, re-engagement, birthday/anniversary rewards.

title: Digital Loyalty Programme Concept
goal: Define the loyalty positioning and benefit stack.

sections.title: Concept
body: Rewards for everyday ethical dining.
Benefits: free items, early offers, local/supplier specials.

title: Loyalty Programme User Journey
goal: Clarify the customer journey stages for loyalty adoption.

sections.title: Journey steps
body: Discover → Sign-up → Earn → Track points → Redeem → Refer friends.

sections.title: Reward structure
body: £1 = 10 points, seasonal/local item bonus points, review referral bonus points.
Threshold ladder: 500 = drink, 1200 = starter, 2500 = voucher.

title: Data Collection and Customer Insights Strategy
goal: Define what data to collect and how to use it responsibly.

sections.title: Collected data
body: Visit frequency, spend level, location preference, dietary preferences, satisfaction ratings.

sections.title: Use cases
body: Tailored offers, menu optimisation, site performance benchmarking.

title: Customer Personalisation Framework
goal: Guide segment-based offers and messaging.

sections.title: Segment-based offers
body: Families → weekend bundles.
Workers → lunch deals.
Ethical diners → supplier menu drops.

title: Experiential Marketing Initiatives
goal: Outline local experiences that bring the rebrand to life.

sections.title: Initiatives
body: Supplier tasting nights, seasonal “local harvest” weekends, community partnerships (schools/charities).

title: Supplier Collaboration and Storytelling Plan
goal: Ensure suppliers are visible across channels and menus.

sections.title: Tactics
body: QR supplier profiles, supplier video reels, local supplier of the month, supplier cards on menus.

title: Staff Brand Training Programme
goal: Equip staff to deliver the brand promise consistently.

sections.title: Modules
body: Brand promise, service behaviours, sustainability knowledge, complaint handling, upselling ethically (bundles/seasonals).

title: Internal Brand Communication Plan
goal: Keep teams aligned with monthly updates and toolkits.

sections.title: Plan
body: Monthly brand toolkit release, site manager briefings, staff updates via internal comms channel.

title: Change Management Plan for Rebranding

sections.title: Steps
body: Communicate “why change”, train leaders first, pilot in 1–2 sites, scale with feedback loop, monitor performance continuously.

goal: Stage the rollout for strategy, identity, and activation.

sections.title: Phases
body: Phase 1: brand strategy + identity.
Phase 2: menu + pricing messaging rollout.
Phase 3: loyalty + CRM launch.
Phase 4: optimisation and campaigns.

title: Delivery Roadmap Timeline

sections.title: Timeline
body: H1: Strategy alignment + identity design.
H2: Menu + pricing comms rollout.
H3: Loyalty + CRM launch.
H4: Optimisation and campaigns.

title: Budget Allocation
goal: Track budget distribution and guardrails for the rebrand.

sections.title: Categories
body: Identity design + signage, website improvements, photography/content, training, CRM/loyalty tools.

body: Greenwashing perceptions → proof points.
Inconsistent execution → central governance.
Staff resistance → training + involvement.
Cost pressure → phased rollout.

body: Brand: awareness + sentiment.
Digital: traffic + conversion.
Customer: NPS + reviews.
Financial: covers + spend + margin.
Operations: service time + consistency.

Improved conversion.
Higher spend through bundles + seasonal upsell.
